summary: Rolando Masferrer was a Cuban exile and former senator involved in activities against the Haitian government and connected to the CIA. Documents suggest he was plotting against Haiti, and there were internal discussions about the legal implications of indicting him due to his claims of U.S. government backing. The CIA was concerned about potential damage to its Miami operations if Masferrer was prosecuted for a planned Haitian invasion. Documents also mention allegations of CIA involvement in his assassination and investigations into his connections within the Cuban exile community. He was also connected to Mitchell Livingston Werbell III.
significance: The documents suggest that Rolando Masferrer was a figure of interest to the CIA, particularly in the context of anti-Castro activities and potential involvement in plots against other governments. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, his connections to the CIA and the Cuban exile community, both of which have been subjects of speculation in relation to the assassination, make him a potentially relevant figure for further investigation. The documents also raise questions about the extent of U.S. government support for his activities and the potential implications of prosecuting him.
